author: {'steamid': '76561197971011081', 'num_games_owned': 1297, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 5640, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2271, 'last_played': 1464456600}
review:
TLTCOC c'est l'histoire d'un humain a t√™te de singe, qui vit dans un monde en papier tout plein de couleurs.
Tout le monde est joyeux, tout le monde il est beau et gentil.
Mais voila qu'un jour certains se mettent en t√™te de d√©terminer qu'elle est la plus jolie des couleurs, et c'est le d√©but des embrouilles.
De fil en aiguille, la ville se s√©pare en quartiers r√©serv√©s √† ceux arborant la bonne couleur: le quartier rouge, le quartier bleu, le quartier vert.

Il reste bien quelques baba cool pour m√©langer les couleurs, mais tous les autres habitants se satisfont de la situation.

Mais voila qu'un jour, pour sauver votre ami malade, vous faites confiance au dieu de la couleur violette ... et foutez un bronx pas possible ! 
La grisaille s'invite √† la f√™te et bouffe toute la couleur. Il ne vous reste plus qu'a faire le m√©nage et a r√©tablir l'√©quilibre.

TLTCOC, c'est choupi ! Mais genre carr√©ment choupinet quoi ! le design est adorable, plein de jolies couleurs et de cr√©atures mignonnes. √áa d√©gouline de sucre de partout.
M√™me la musique est entra√Ænante, chouette, parfois un peu jazzy et souvent bien classe.

En terme de gameplay on est sur un m√©lange de plateformer, combats √† la batman (mais en light quand m√™me) et puzzle game.
Tout tourne autour de la couleur et de ce qu'on peut en faire. Le personnage principal va acqu√©rir, au fur et a mesure de son aventure, le pouvoir d'utiliser diff√©rentes couleurs.
En combat, le rouge fait des d√©g√¢ts, le vert fait fuir, le bleu stun.
Pendant les phases de puzzle game, on utilisera ces couleurs sur des champignons qui auront diff√©rentes r√©actions. Le rouge sur un gros champignon le fait sautiller alors que le petit champignon explosera.
Et tout fonctionne parfaitement.

Au d√©but de l'aventure on trouvera surement tout cela assez simple, en se disant que c'est plut√¥t orient√© pour les m√¥mes. Mais ne vous y trompez pas, ca se corse rapidement pour atteindre une difficult√© correcte.
Mon gamin y jouant en parall√®le, je pense qu'il va avoir de s√©rieux probl√®mes a passer quelques zones.

Pour r√©sumer : 
C'est mignon, attachant, choupinet, le gameplay est int√©ressant, ca dure en gros 7 heures, que demande le peuple ?

author: {'steamid': '76561198034063409', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 807, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 629, 'last_played': 1425741816}
review:
First impressions are very important when it comes to making a game, and when it comes to this one, it isn't hard to see why a lot of people dismiss it as a "meh" game: Combat is rather simplistic, the story clearly is about the evils of racism and how it ruins communites, and infamously about how it feels nothing like what it claims to be paying homage to.

But then you play a little more, and you see that the game touches down on more than just racism during your 5-7 hour adventure. It will delve into the dangers of excessive paranoia and fear of the unknown, tell the story of a man who wastes his life away at the bar instead of trying to solve all his problems like a man, and of course that there is nothing wrong with helping someone that you normally aren't really friends with.. In dark times, even the bullies that pester you need your help, and in turn can become a close friend.

Combat, while it still is button mashy, at least gets a bit more interesting as you progress through the game, getting new powers that allow you to switch it up a bit, such as the power to stun a large enemy so you can deal a critical blow from behind, or even cause them to suddenly start running in fear off of a cliff or into spiked bushes of death. Late in the game there is even some enemies that require you to vary your attacks in order to beat it, so you can't just button mash your whole way, as well as the fact that sometimes you need to use a later-earned ranged attack to deal with other threats, giving you something different besides jush mashing the left mouse button.

However, the game most certainly is no Banjo & Kazooie or Jak and Daxter, what with the collection element of the game being completely optional and only used for small bonus content, nothing really big (unless you like lookin at concept art), and the platforming being mostly simplified (I say mostly, because there still is a few segments that require your input, such as jumping during rail grinds and the general timing of platforming). Rather, this is more of a 3D semi-platformer bawler of sorts, and for the kids, I think it is a fairly decent little game. Not only does it leave you to ponder a few things afterwards about the content it tackles, but it also is a fun title full of life and personality, and a few chuckles here and there.. For the hardcore sort, however, maybe you might wanna look elsewhere, because while there is some challenge in this game, I don't think it'll be enough to keep more serious gamers engaged for long, as indicated again by the negative reputation this game sadly has.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980199331', 'num_games_owned': 3533, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 793, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 756, 'last_played': 1561804498}
review:
Artistiquement, The Last Tinker se pose l√†. La musique est envo√ªtante, et pour ce qui est du look... Regardez les screenshots et les vid√©os.

Le probl√®me, c'est qu'√† c√¥t√© de √ßa, c'est la banqueroute.

Commence par oublier les gros noms du platformer 3D pl√¢tr√©s partout sur la page du magasin, lecteur : s'il y a bien eu inspiration, le jeu est bien loin de tout √ßa. D'abord au niveau du collectathon, puisque les 80 pinceaux cach√©s ne te demanderont gu√®re d'efforts √† trouver, mais surtout au niveau du gameplay.

D'abord, il n'y a pas de saut. Les changements de hauteur sont contextuels. Du moins pour ce qui est de monter. Pour descendre, par contre, tu as toute libert√© de te casser la gueule. Je m'interroge encore sur l'int√©r√™t d'un syst√®me le cul entre deux chaises, mais passons.

Ensuite, la course est optionnelle, et la marche le d√©faut. Ce serait cool. Si la marche avait un int√©r√™t quelconque plus de 10 secondes de jeu, dans un unique passage √©troit o√π les c√¥t√©s sont bard√©s de buissons √©pineux. Oui, c'est litt√©ralement le seul passage du jeu o√π marcher a le moindre int√©r√™t (et encore est-il anecdotique, puisqu'au vu du nombre plus que g√©n√©reux de PV donn√©s au joueur, m√™me en fon√ßant dans le tas √ßa risque fort de ne pas mal tourner). Bref, on passe DIX HEURES le bouton RT enfonc√©. DIX HEURES. CONTRE DIX SECONDES. Tu permets ? je reviens, juste le temps de charger le fusil √† pompe.

Ensuite, le combat. Le dernier Spyro auquel j'aie jou√©, c'√©tait sur Wii, me demande m√™me pas le titre, √ßa m'a jamais laiss√© un souvenir imp√©rissable, Spyro. J'admets. Mais du moins avait-il l'avantage d'offrir une vari√©t√© √† la limite de l'obsc√®ne. Dans Tinker, tu peux acheter des upgrades, mais elles n'ont aucun int√©r√™t. Aucun. AUCUN. AU-CUN. J'ai fini le jeu de bout en bout en utilisant EXCLUSIVEMENT les attaques de base (et le bouton RT, est-il besoin de le rappeler). Je ne saurais m√™me pas te dire √† quoi ressemble le reste : je m'en suis jamais servi. Je me souviens qu'√† un moment de l'intro on m'a appris √† esquiver avec RB, mais l√† o√π c'est rigolo avec Hand of Fate, ici c'est juste facepalmesque dans sa contradiction avec le RT qu'on oblige le joueur √† enfoncer. Jamais de challenge, jamais de situations √©pineuses. Bref : c'est fade, c'est morne, c'est tout √† l'inverse du principe du jeu et m√™me de son nom.

Ensuite, le gameplay d'une mani√®re plus g√©n√©rique. Simple : coinc√© entre son saut contextuel, ses chutes sans pr√©ambule, sa rigidit√© quasi-cadav√©rique dans le level design, sa platitude presque constante et ses rails tant propres que figur√©s, c'est un v√©ritable carnage. On s'emmerde de bout en bout, entre d√©placements pour l'histoire et parcours d'une map plus lin√©aire qu'un Call of Duty dans une civi√®re et ses secrets aussi bien planqu√©s que le monde 2-1 de Super Mario. Comprenne qui pourra.

Les unlocks ? Des artworks. Cool. Des modes √† la con. Rien √† foutre. Une ar√®ne. Une... Attends. Tu viens de me carrer le syst√®me de combat le plus pourrave que j'aie vu ces trois derni√®res ann√©es entre les mains, et t'as encore le culot de me coller UNE AR√àNE ? Heureusement pour toi que j'ai utilis√© mes derni√®res r√©serves d'anthrax sur ma review d'Escape Goat 2, toi aussi je t'aurais donn√© des cours de base sur le metal.

Le syst√®me Biggs/Boomer ? Sympa, mais au final chiant. Soit on siffle cette/ces bestiole(s) pour qu'elles suivent, auquel cas les positionner o√π on veut tient de la gageure (fort heureusement uniquement demand√© quand on veut les changer de forme), soit on les transporte dans le cas de Boomer, mais alors non seulement on ne peut plus courir, mais en prime la vitesse de marche d√©j√† digne d'un grabataire asthmatique se retrouve encore multipli√©e par z√©ro (manquerait plus qu'elle ait √©t√© divis√©e, tu me diras, lecteur).

Le mini-jeu de l'orchestre ? J'ai juste un truc √† dire. Si t'as d√©j√† touch√© √† une SNES, tu veux pas approcher ce truc avec une hazmat et la manette d'un autre au bout d'un b√¢ton, lecteur. J'ai d√©j√† eu du mal √† retenir l'inversion BAYX -> ABXY, alors me demander de retenir les COULEURS des boutons de la manette ? Juste... Va voir chez les serbes les films √† titre pourri, tu veux ?

Sans compter les probl√®mes de contr√¥les. Je veux dire, au d√©but du jeu, on te dit deux choses : RB sert 1. √† esquiver ; 2. √† descendre de ta plate-forme sur√©lev√©e. Ouais. Sauf que RT fonctionne tout aussi bien et est d'office enfonc√©, donc t'en as strictement rien √† foutre. Jusqu'√† environ 8h dans le jeu, o√π UNE plate-forme REFUSE l'utilisation de RT. Et bien √©videmment apr√®s 8h, as-tu retenu ce d√©tail, lecteur ? Honn√™tement ? NON. C'est pas plus compliqu√© que √ßa. On t'inculque un truc pendant 8h, le virer apr√®s c'est du foutage de gueule.

Le boss de fin ? Le seul v√©ritable boss du jeu en fait ? Juste chiant, incapable de viser, pr√©dictible sans exp√©rience, mou, bref absolument obsc√®ne vu sa prestigieuse position.

Les s√©quences sur rail propre ? Disons que tu as ici un bel exemple de dev qui n'a pas compris que quand on veut mettre un obstacle dans un virage, la moindre des choses quand on est propre, justement, est d'avertir le joueur en pivotant la cam√©ra un peu plus d'un vingti√®me de seconde avant l'apparition de l'obstacle en question. En particulier quand t'abuses du motion blur.

Le doublage ? L'id√©e est bien, hein. Je dis pas le contraire. Mais tu sais pourquoi les gens normaux grincent des dents devant les vieux Enix genre Illusion of Gaia ? Parce que les bipbipbipbipbipbip, c'est ignoble. Alors pourquoi diable avoir foutu ici une voix qui fait LITT√âRALEMENT "ouiiiiiiiiin, ouin ouin ouiiiiiin. Ouiiiiin, ouiiiin" ? Mmh ?

Le syst√®me de checkpoints ? √Ä moiti√© dans le caniveau : uniquement utilisables sur la partie en cours - besoin de prendre l'air ? Bah tu te retaperas ta map depuis le d√©but, √ßa te fera les pieds. 

Et les dialogues avec, apr√®s tout un bouton skip, c'est pour les faibles. Tu reprendras bien un peu de "ouiiiiiiiiin, ouin ouin ouiiiiiin. Ouiiiiin, ouiiiin", non ? C'pas comme si √ßa allait te taper sur le syst√®me √† la quatri√®me seconde.

Ah, oui. Et dernier d√©tail : c'est optimis√© √† la truelle. Quand l'AO te fait pas ramer mais que les R√âFLEXIONS mettent ton PC √† genoux, tu sais qu'y a un truc pourri chez les Danois.

√âvite, lecteur. √âvite, √† moins de vouloir finir comme moi. Meurtri √† tendance meurtri√®re. Bon, ceci dit, si tu t'obstines la VF est pratiquement irr√©prochable. Mais c'est cher payer pour quelques lignes de fran√ßais correct.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990947284', 'num_games_owned': 5370, 'num_reviews': 1354, 'playtime_forever': 151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1420737630}
review: Colorful, interesting and simple 3D-Platforming game with great controls. If you liked games like Banjo&Kazooie back in the day, you will enjoy this one as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001334265', 'num_games_owned': 535, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 478, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 478, 'last_played': 1421508023}
review:
General: 
- 6 hour story
- There are 4 difficulty levels(easy, normal, hard, instant death), and hard was not difficult at all
- Really linear
Pros:
- Great use of colors
- Really nice and simple levels, very nice animations
- GREAT soundtrack
- I personally really liked story
- Very good use of port on keyboard(it didn't feel at all that I was using a controller on a keyboard)
Cons:
- Not much replayability
- Possibly too easy(puzzles, fights, levels)
- "Auto-jumps"
- Very little power-up as the game goes on
- (I feel it's important but you can mark it off)Little characterization of protagonist, I mean.. there were why and what that didn't get answered and I felt the lack of depth.


Overall I DON'T think it's worth buying it full price(Right now it's 20‚Ç¨) but makes a nice easy and cozy game if you're NOT a hardcore gamer.
Music is great and doesn't get annoying (as often happens when you stay in one level for too much), level design is really friendly and there is something I just loved about the coloring. Controls aren't bulky but maybe a bit too automatic.
Still, if you're thinking of buying it, maybe wait for it to be on sales.
8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197970507922', 'num_games_owned': 1275, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 771, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 771, 'last_played': 1418783947}
review:
I actually played til my wrists ached.  I don't think I've done that since Super Mario 64.  It's not quite on that level, but it's not too far off.  

I was a bit concerned about the stealth aspect, but thankfully there's only a couple short areas of it and they're not too bad.  The 2nd stealth section was pretty grueling at first, but then I realized I was being an idiot and the security system only sees you if you' moving.   

That bit aside though, the world is refreshingly unique with fun, bright colors, the level design is great, story is creative, controls are spot on and the difficulty feels just right from start to finish.  This is probably one I'll come back to again in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026325298', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 125, 'playtime_forever': 762, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 762, 'last_played': 1419716673}
review:
[h1]Score: 8/10[/h1]

[u][b]Similar Games[/b][/u]
Banjo Kazooie

[u][b]Overview[/b][/u]
The City of Colors has has citizens who are devided by the color they are. There are four districts which are Red, Blue, Green, and Mixed. You play as a monkey who also happens to be the main character and a Tinker. Everything in the City of Colors is created by making paintings. The Red, Blue, and Green districts all have a spirit temple which houses the spirit. A Tinker can use the powers of these spirits. Once you accidently release the bleakness into the world it is your job to save Color Town from the bleakness and itself.

[u][b]The Good[/b][/u]
The plot is actually meaningful not just because of the implication of race, but it actually implies to look beyond your differences in general. I say this because the colors aren't just a different shade, but they have very different personalities. The powers are well done in combat, but they really shine as puzzles solving mechanics. The graphics are adorable even if they do tend to be slightly to kiddish. The music and gibberish voices are also pretty good.

[u][b]The Bad[/b][/u]
The platforming tends to feel a little to on rails. The game does come off a bit to kiddish. The vending machine feature for enhancing moves just improves power and duration instead of new features.

[u][b]Conclusion[/b][/u]
This game is actually pretty astounding. I mean you have a studio that is basically unknown creating one of the only descent 3D platformers on steam. If you are a fan of the old school 3D platform games this is a must own.

[u][b]Value[/b][/u]
This is a very well done platformer and I'd value it at around $15 worth of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019266495', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1138, 'last_played': 1427302162}
review:
I am not normally one to write reviews for games, just not that great a gamer and don't think my input would mean much to  others out there, but this game? this game I HAVE to. 

This is an amazing game! Not perfect, no it has its flaws I will get to, but something everyone should try.

First it reminds me of my old platform days, playing Jax and Dexter or the like, bright colors, silly sounds for voices, all of it is here. The plot is cute, and kept me involved with just enough story. And the story, well thought out and didn't end how I thought, very nice from start to end. Its controls are easy to pick up and get going too, no long drawn out tutorials needed here.

Now as I said the game DOES have a few small flaws, but other then a making me frown a few moments, didn't stop me at all. The camera can get a tiny bit annoying in spots, like in some of the tight fighting areas. I did get lost a few times, and its a little dark on the 'inside' areas. Also, it felt a little short, and I had wished for a little more variety in enemies. 

TL:DR: get this game, its a fun throw back to older platform days that will have you smiling through it all, with a fun plot lesson to learn. It does have some control flaws, but they won't stop you from playing through this amazing game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970735557', 'num_games_owned': 1153, 'num_reviews': 258, 'playtime_forever': 281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 281, 'last_played': 1419228432}
review: Well, I enjoyed that a lot. It's a bit of a PS2-era game in a PS4 world, especially in terms of the sparsely-populated world, but the imagination on display is satisfying, the story is quite sweet, and for a team of nine people, this is an excellent piece of work. The downsides are a slightly sticky control system (with a dodge which never quite works), and a very shaky framerate. But the upsides well outweigh those downsides. Recommended for a gentle weekend of nostalgia.

review:

- Lovable characters

10/10 Will replay the hell out of it after I'm done. Sequel anyone?

author: {'steamid': '76561198080598417', 'num_games_owned': 504, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 2010, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1004, 'last_played': 1468865608}
review:

Highly recommended to players of all ages.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112335919', 'num_games_owned': 329, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 432, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 429, 'last_played': 1451439952}
review: My only complaint is "jumping" is rahter automatic. You hold forward and space bar and he jumped from place to place automatically.  Still gratifying.  The battles with the white enemy guys can be difficult (quite) and I'm only on normal mode.  The color and artwork is awesome.  The 3D feel is also great - very much feeling line the old nintendo games of their day.  There is so much going on and so much detail that seems to go on foreever.  I bought about 80-90 games in the past 1.5 years off steam.  Borderlands (1, 2) clearly my favorites, but this is a close contender) really since I got this I haven't been able to play anything else.  It's A LOT OF FUN. There is a lot of game play.  I THINK I'm about 1/2 way through it and I've played for several hours.   Less than 7 bucks on sale?  SNATCH IT.  Actually I'd be pleased at 9.99 even maybe 19.95.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044856783', 'num_games_owned': 772, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 706, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 633, 'last_played': 1431115001}
review:
This is a very good game, don't expect something like Jak & Daxter or Banyo Kazoiee because it's very different and I'm not sure that this game should be called a 3D platformer (I think this game is better described like an action adventure game).
This game delivers some platforming(sadly, with AC controls), some combat and some puzzles, none of them is done great(all  of them works well), but every one is delivered with the perfect  pacing that makes a very satisfying game, even if none of the gameplay parts are very good.
Now, the things where this game is oustanding: it's very good written, the music is awesome, and. like I said previously, the pacing of this game is very  good.
FInally, I have to praise its writting: this game presents very mature themes in a simplistic and kids friendly way, have well developed characters and a consistent storyline.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040880154', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1002, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 724, 'last_played': 1418887024}

    [*]Has somehow flown totally under the radar
[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561197984548831', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1417906165}
review: This is a cute change of pace from Shadows of Mordor and other dark, violent games that I love so much. The mechanics are easy, the controls are nice. It's controller friendly if you think a PC is an Xbox and missions are simple.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964912059', 'num_games_owned': 1013, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1399843071}
review:
Not surprising given the name I guess, but this game is so remarkably colourful and vibrant that in a sea of games that go for muddy browns it was a welcomed breath of fresh air. The character designs of the weird and wonderful people and enemies you meet also show a lot of creativity went into it. This is a rare type of game these days. As the developers themselves say - if you liked Jak and Daxter and/or Banjo Kazooie you'll probably love this.

I was asked by the developers to take a look at the game in my first impressions series, if you'd like to see it in motion as well as hear some more thoughts consider looking at the video below.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=12L34eLKxQw

author: {'steamid': '76561198073841664', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 181, 'last_played': 1413331343}
review:
Not liking what I'm playing so far. Sure it's a beautiful game and even though it claims inspiration from great 3d platformers\collect-a-thons of yore, a platformer in the strictest sense of the word it is not as it doesn't have a jump button. There's way too much automatic nonsense happening in this game for me. For instance, to run across some platforms on water you hold RT and watch an animation play out. To climb a rope\vine\ladder you hold RT and watch an animation play out. To swing across some gaps in the air...take a guess at what you do, if you said carefully time your swings and press jump at the height of your swing you'd be fkn wrong as all you're doing in this game is holding RT and watching some animations play out.

I'm glad that this game was inspired by the games listed on it's marketing description however it does very little and I mean very little with those inspirations. Now I was not expecting a clone of those game because that'd be extremely stupid, but I was at least expecting an enjoyable 3d platformer but all I get is a mountain of dialogue (which may be good who knows), dodgy controls, boring\repetitive combat and some automatic platforming.

[h1]Verdict:[/h1]
I doubt I'll finish this game so buy at your own discretion. Hopefully A Hat in Time delivers.

review: The Last Tinker: City of Colors  es una gran apuesta por parte de Mimimi Productions. Con un estilo de plataforma en tres dimensiones, que nos hace recordar a los grandes cl√°sicos como Super Mario 64, Jak & Daxter o Crash Bandicoot. Si bien es un producto Indie, no tiene nada de desperdicio este juego de aventura muy entretenido, sobre todo para los m√°s chiquitos de la casa. Porque al principio resulta tan infantil que empalaga, aunque cuando vamos avanzando en la historia el juego resulta ser m√°s entretenido.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995168801', 'num_games_owned': 456, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 355, 'last_played': 1495302265}
review:
The Last Tinker is, perhaps, one of THE best games I've played in the past few years. The entire game somehow managed to mix a bunch of different things -- the old quirky feeling of games like Banjo-Kazooie and Spyro, the free-range parkour of Prince of Persia, an almost whimsical setting/look, an utterly terrifying villain/force, and a serious plot -- while still feeling like something completely fresh and brand new rather than just rehashing old nostalgia. Everything about this game is good, and the mistakes it makes are few.

Let's start with the music. The music is amazing and well-made, and absolutely catchy at times. There is a point where the music goes utterly harsh and terrible (as in badly done), but that is a completely plot-related reason. All of the tracks fit their areas fairly well, and if there was any unfitting combinations, it was subtle enough that I never even came close to noticing it. In fact, the music is so important to the game that there are sections where you have to jump or move in time with the beat in order to progress, which makes you really feel immersed in it!

The graphics are absolutely amazing. They tie well together with each other, and they look unique. Unlike a lot of other realistically-styled games (which could almost be interchangable), the whimiscal, I'd say almost coloring-book-and-culturally-designed-look of this game stands out; it reminds me of designs and artwork used for things like pinatas almost, with every character and area having multiple patterns. Every stage and character looks unique (group-wise, if not individually) on its normal design... until the Bleakness runs through and makes it all monochrome and same-looking. However, rather than detract from the game, it [b]adds[/b] to it, showing you just how terrifying the force you're up against is and just what the world is when you strip away its individuality and destroy everything that made it unique.

The plot and writing is some of the best I've ever seen. Like any writing, it can hiccup a bit at times, but overall it's absolutely fantastic, the characters are amusing and quirky and tend to feel unique, and even though he never speaks a word your main character feels just as unique as the rest of them. The plot, itself, is actually quite terrifying, and deeper than it first appears to be. Without spoiling anything, it's just as good as the rest of the writing, but stands [b]with[/b] it rather than [b]against[/b] it despite all the differences.


Now for the negative parts.

Firstly, the game can be very confusing at times. While you do have a way to show where you're supposed to go, it can be outright unhelpful at times, leaving you without knowing where you're supposed to go or what you're supposed to do when you get there. Usually, a mix of that direction system, backtracking, and exploration can help you find your way, but it's definitely something that can be a bit frustrating at times.

Secondly, a few of the battles can be incredibly frustrating to outright unfair. Small platforms with shield-generating enemies and tons of normal enemies (that you can't hit until the shield-ones are gone) are not unknown, and a lot of the more difficult battles you can't actually run past and skip. Additionally, if you die, you have to start the entire battle over again. On top of all this, enemies can be placed very nastily and with far too many numbers, making just running through areas as fast as possible sometimes the best course of action, which detracts from the experience as you're missing out on the beautifully-crafted areas.

Thirdly, the Color Spirits' powers feel vastly underused. While it does give you more in-battle powers and even a small handful of out-of-battle-powers, the game hypes up Koru and the tinkers in general as some powerful, creative force, yet you so very rarely [i]feel[/i] like such a force when your powers are mostly just used in fighting enemies. This is especially true for the last Color Spirit that you get, which is only used for a single thing and only in the final boss fight.


Overall, I would say that The Last Tinker: City of Colors is an absolutely amazing game. They do so much RIGHT with it, and it feels like an amazing, enjoyable, and -- unlike many games -- [i]unique[/i] experience which is sure to stand out against the crowd of samey-old-type games.

Pick it up. If you like platforming, or unique games, or fun plays, pick it up. Trust me: you won't be sorry.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998320571', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 95, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1410316572}
review: I may have liked The Last Tinker more if I had gone in with the correct expectations. This was supposed to be a platformer in the vein of Banjo Kazooie, but it is nothing like that game. There isn't even a dedicated jump button! Gameplay centers mostly around the primitive fighting mechanics which become tiresome very quickly. I want to love this game. It's absolutely gorgeous, it's just not very fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069874650', 'num_games_owned': 486, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 963, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 963, 'last_played': 1404690472}
review:
8/10

√ìtimo:
-Trilha sonora
-Criatividade geral do jogo
-Jogo bem finalizado, sem bugs, com suporte para controle e todos os ajustes que um jogo de PC deve ter.

Bom:
-Level Design
-Gr√°ficos
-Puzzles 'leves' mas divertidos
-Mecanica 'Le Parkour' autom√°tica funciona bem
-Hist√≥ria simples, mas divertida
-Inimigos tem pouca variabilidade, mas cumprem seu papel

Ruim
-Pre√ßo
-Muito linear
-Dublagem pode ser irritante as vezes

Muito ruim
-Personagens pouco carism√°ticos, previs√≠veis e repetitivos

Jogo bem divertido, com um desenho muito inovador e criativo dos levels (apesar de parecer meio confuso na primeira impress√£o) e alguns puzzles legais, apesar de bem f√°ceis. 

Ao contr√°rio do que a descri√ß√£o sugere, n√£o √© exatamente um jogo plataformer. Hoje em dia t√° dificil classificar um jogo assim, mas eu chamaria de "aventura", j√° que as a√ß√µes do tipo pular entre diversas pedras no meio de um lago s√£o feitas de maneira 'autom√°tica' pelo game.

A hist√≥ria √© meio infantilizada, mas boa no geral, e muito criativa, bem diferente do que tem no mercado atual.

O controle do X-box funciona perfeito no jogo, plug e play, nada de ficar ajustando controle e tal. E os gr√°ficos s√£o at√© surpreendentes, possui cen√°rios lindos, dentro do estilo sugerido nas fotos, mas √© bem leve, roda suave. Tamb√©m n√£o vi nenhum bug que mere√ßa ser mencionado. Mas uma das melhores partes √© a trilha sonora. Faz tempo que n√£o via um jogo com musicas t√£o legais. Diferentes, at√© ex√≥ticas, mas legais =)

Se voce gostou de jogos como Spyro, Psychonauts e at√© Mario 64 (guardadas as devidas propor√ß√µes rs) voce provavelmente ir√° gostar deste tamb√©m.


DEFEITOS:
- Primeiro o pre√ßo, t√° meio fora do que deveria ser. R$25 por um jogo Indie, que d√° umas 8h de gameplay (+6h pra completar 100%) est√° de bom tamanho.

- Este estilo de jogo fica melhor num jogo mais aberto que esse, como em Spyro ou at√© no Mario 64, onde podemos, at√© certo ponto, escolher qual fase iremos jogar. The Last Tinker √© bem mais linear, mas o problema maior √© que, depois de terminar a hist√≥ria, n√£o √© poss√≠vel visitar os lugares para procurar itens deixados pra tr√°s e tal, o jogo passa os cr√©ditos e volta pro menu inicial... D√° pra jogar os niveis de novo, atrav√©s de uma fun√ß√£o no menu, mas o player √© obrigado a refazer toda a hist√≥ria e entrentar os mesmos inimigos... Seria mais interessante se mostrasse o lugar sendo reconstruido ou coisa assim.

- Os personagens... talvez o maior problema do jogo... o principal √© pouco carism√°tico, 'mudo' e suas anima√ß√µes s√£o repetitivas. Mas o problema maior √© que existem uma meia d√∫zia de personagens √∫nicos, o resto dos NPC s√£o todos iguais entre si, o que deixa tudo muito repetitivo e at√© dificulta a navega√ß√£o pelos mapas, j√° que √© todo mundo igual... Isso fica ainda pior quando se pensa que o jogo se passa num mundo feito de papel, cola e tinta (acho que √© isso)... os cen√°rios s√£o t√£o bem elaborados, mas os personagens realmente deixam a desejar... parece que acabou a inspira√ß√£o dos desenvolvedores.

- A l√≠ngua falada na cidade √© digna de The Sims... apenas uns murm√∫rios sem sentido, que s√£o legendados... at√© a√≠ tudo bem, melhor uma dublagem sem sentido do que uma com sentido mal feita, mas em algumas cenas muito longas isso enche o saco, e n√£o √© poss√≠vel pular completamente as cenas, apenas aceler√°-las.

No geral, eu digo que vale a pena, apontei os defeitos do jogo, se eles n√£o te incomodam, v√° em frente e divirta-se!

EDIT: mudaram o pre√ßo de mais de R$30,00 para R$19,99, mas √© comum promo√ß√£o que deixa o jogo a 3 reais. Provavelmente estar√° entre os 3 reais mais bem gastos da sua vida

author: {'steamid': '76561197963922976', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 415, 'last_played': 1403968489}
review:
I notice that The Last Tinker: City of Colors is often compared to Banjo-Kazooie and said to be a platformer. I don't think this is an accurate comparison. This isn't to say that The Last Tinker is bad. Only that other games bear a better comparison. I think that a better comparison is to a game like Beyond Good and Evil, or perhaps 3d Zelda titles. I hope the reason for this comparison will become clear through the review.

First of all the platforming in The Last Tinker is context based and not free. You cannot actually jump at will in this game. You run at edges and leap to the next designated spot.  The challenge is not based on jumping onto difficult platforms, but on timing your leaps between platforms. The platforming is more a puzzle than a test of dexterity. The platforms can be considered more a mode of transport than the main challenge.   

What you do spend a lot of you time doing is fighting. The combat is basically puzzle based. You have a couple of unique strikes, which are useful against certain enemies. You often have to choose which enemy to defeat first, and use your skills to keep the other enemies off you. The combat feels a little strange. You can approach the same battle in slightly different ways, with one time earning your death and the next trouncing everyone quickly. I believe this may be the result of the puzzle emphasis on combat. If you abuse your somewhat very powerful abilities you will win. If you go in as a traditional brawler and don‚Äôt abuse your abilities, you won‚Äôt do well at all. What I mean is that the combat is not nuanced. You solve the combat, you don‚Äôt win through strength or dexterity. This would make it similar to the platforming in that the challenge is solving the situation. Enacting your solution is usually quite easy.

The checkpoint system is generous, and unlimited. So any frustrations that may be felt are reduced to very minimal levels.

Puzzles are the fundamental challenge of the game. This is experienced through both the above mentioned combat and platforming, and also normal puzzles you would normally encounter during an adventure game. Challenges are usually not highly dexterity based.  You quite often interact with other characters to solve puzzles. The puzzles are quite varied. While no puzzle is particularly difficult, each puzzle meshes very well with the universe. In a sense, you learn about the world through solving puzzles.

The overall story is very important to the structure of The Last Tinker. Every level feels like it advances the plot, and feels like a natural extension of the previous events. The exploration is linear. There is no hub and there are no levels that branch off. There is a continuous story. The levels are chapters in a story.  This means that the gameplay always feels wedded to the world you are exploring. I never felt like anything I was doing was game logic or ‚Äòjust because‚Äô you needed something to be in the way. 
You spend a lot of the game surrounded by other inhabitants, and this goes a long way towards making the world feel believable. You interact with, if not every inhabitant of the world, what feels like enough inhabitants to understand and care about the world. And the main character feels like his contribution to the world is defined by a heroism of spirit, and not of being the strongest person around. The other characters you interact with achieve a balance of being very defined, and in a sense extreme, but also being human and relatable.

The story is very well told. It has a fairy tale quality, which means that while the story is not complicated, it does demonstrate something fundamental about humanity.

I highly recommend this game to people interested in an adventure built on a fairy tale style story and immersion in a fantasy world. If you are looking for a intricate gameplay based game then it is better to look elsewhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060539903', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 684, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1636962874}
review:
The Last Tinker: City of Colors is very unique and creative. There is a lot of love put into this game even its still being worked on. As far as Gameplay it's pretty standard. Combat is pretty smooth, and sometimes can be too easy, but if you put the game on hard you'll have a good challenge anything higher will make you go nuts trust me. Characters are cute and remind me and couple of my buddies of viva pinata, but with much more color hence the name no pun intended. However be aware that sometimes you will run into things like bugs, that has happened to me yet knock on wood, but the developers are very active as this game grows. 

As you get more and more items or powers challenges become really interesting and sometimes tedious. Might be because I suck at this game, but keep playing it because I the story is abstract and something I would've never expected especially for a game like this. There is a lot of light humor and it's great for a game like this. I would hope that this game gets released on a console like playstation, xbox, nintendo consoles because it would really work well.

This game is solid and for all ages. If I had to rate it this game is 7/10 and although it's still in working progress there is enough content for you to play for hours.

review: Originelles, abwechslungsreiches Spiel, allerdings kein klassischer Platformer im Sinne eines Jump&Run, weil man nicht wirklich aktiv springen kann (lediglich √ºber Hindernisse auf den Rails). Sonst funktioniert Klettern und H√ºpfen praktisch automatisch. Man muss nur die Schultertaste gedr√ºckt halten und Koru in die entsprechende Richtung bewegen. Herunterfallen ist dabei praktisch ausgeschlossen. Das Spiel hat jedoch andere St√§rken! Lustige Charaktere, wie die Farbgeister, Korus Freund Tap oder  explodierende Pilzwesen, die einem den Weg freir√§umen oder auf denen man durch Hindernisse reiten kann, bringen viel Abwechslung ins Spiel und lassen nie Langeweile aufkommen. Kein Abschnitt ist wie der andere. Die Spielzeit von 8-10 Stunden, die man ben√∂tigt, um das Spiel durchzuspielen, ist ebenfalls sehr ordentlich. Meine Wertung: 80 von 100 Punkten.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033784398', 'num_games_owned': 643, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 464, 'last_played': 1404860803}
review: A fantastic and charming little game that reminds me a lot of N64 era platformers that I enjoyed immensely. The game has a very colourful world and a linear as well as a somewhat childlike story but was still a pretty fun experience. The gameplay consisted of some simple platforming which mostly took the form of holding a button as well as some combat that loosely reminded me of the Arkham series combat, though not nearly as fluid. Overall if you are looking for a colourful and feel-good game I'd definitely recommend this hidden gem!

author: {'steamid': '76561198012493948', 'num_games_owned': 799, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 885, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 835, 'last_played': 1400000553}
review:
The Last Tinker: City of Colors √® un buon adventure, da consigliare a tutti quei giocatori privi di pregiudizi nei confronti di prodotti spesso bollati come infantili. Avere appeal sul pubblico pi√π giovane non √® un crimine, soprattutto se le meccaniche proposte stimolano la materia grigia e intrigano con una progressione bilanciata. Non √® un gioco perfetto: manca di un vero endgame, di quest secondarie, di una struttura aperta, e il sistema di combattimento non √® straordinario. Tuttavia √® un prodotto divertente, pieno di personaggi che difficilmente dimenticheremo, e rimane caldamente consigliato a tutti gli appassionati di adventure game.

+ Vario e divertente
+ Puzzle piacevoli
+ Accessibile ma gratificante
+ Design molto ispirato
- Alcuni lo bolleranno come prodotto per bambini
- Sistema di combattimento poco approfondito
- Bassa longevit√†

Recensione completa @ http://www.nrsgamers.it/the-last-tinker-city-of-colors/

author: {'steamid': '76561198067083019', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1853, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 344, 'last_played': 1588457470}
review:
Zu aller erst: Ich bin Fan dieses Spiels und habe mich schon vor Release dar√ºber informiert, Let's Plays geschaut, News gelesen, Screenshots angeguckt etc. und  hab mich dadurch aufgeladen. 
Was allerdings auch bedeutet, dass ich hohe Erwartungen an das Spiel hatte, also keineswegs unkritisch an das Spiel heran gegangen bin.

Was ich mir erwartet habe? "Kindheit Reloaded" und endlich mal beweisen, dass der Pc und seine Spieler durchaus eine Masse sind, f√ºr die es sich lohnt Spiele wie "The Last Tinker" oder "A hat in Time" zu entwickeln und Nintendo NICHT das Vorrecht an solchen Spielen hat, nur weil sie ein Monopol auf die Kindheitshelden haben. 
Wer an Spielen wie Banjo Kazooie, Zelda, Super Mario etc. keinen Spa√ü hat, der wird aber auch hier schnell m√ºde. Der ist aber gewiss nicht die Zielgruppe.

Aber nun zur Review: 

Die Story: Die Story ist nat√ºrlich, wie zu erwarten, kindgerecht. Allerdings mit einem Kern, der auch ein √§lteres bzw. erwachsenes Publikum anspricht. (Ich bin 17 Jahre alt und genie√üe es sehr, endlich mal keine Nazis abzuknallen oder Zombies zu t√∂ten.) Diese ganze Geschichte √ºbertr√§gt sich, wie ich finde, gut auf die Welt und wirkt authentisch. 
Was die Linearit√§t angeht w√ºrde ich behaupten, dass es Phasen gibt, in denen man gef√ºhrt wird, man aber durchaus seine Verschnaufpausen hat, in denen man sich umgucken kann.
Die gesamte Idee, dass alles aus Papier und Kleber ist, jede Farbe f√ºr eine eigene Emotion steht und verschiedene F√§higkeiten besitzt, finde ich auch gut und dient als willkommene Abwechslung.
Was ich besonders hervorheben will, ist die (bis zu meinem jetzigen Stand zumindest) Entwicklung der Geschichte,weil sie sich nachvollziehbar und trotzdem Spannend/√ºberraschend entfaltet.
Die Welt an sich gef√§llt mir sehr gut und auch die Charaktere, die teilweise mit so herrlich kindlichen Spr√ºchen herumposaunen passen klasse in diese Welt (vor allem weil ihre Spr√ºche auch auf die Welt bezogen sind. Kleines Beispiel: "Du hast dir ein paar neue Farben verdient...[Als Kampfansage]"). Auch die Bindung, die zwischen Tap und Koru besteht gef√§llt mir sehr gut und gibt der ganzen Sache einen "(nicht nervige)-Navy und Link"-Charme.

Das Gameplay: Das Gameplay besteht aus Jump n' Run Elementen, einem "Batman-√§hnlichem" Kampfsystem und diversen, kurzen "Zelda-Tempel"-R√§tseln. Besonders hervorheben m√∂chte ich, dass es freischaltbare Kombos bzw. Verst√§rkungen gibt und verschiedene Gegnertypen, die je nach Kombination und Auftreten ein anderes System im Kampf verlangen. 
Der Schwierigkeitsgrad ist auch auf normal (Es gibt verschiedene Stufen: Kinder, Normal, Schwer, Soforttod [man kann jederzeit die Schwierigkeit anpassen]) √ºberraschend knackig; allerdings nicht frustrierend. Vor allem weil das Game- Over kein wirklicher Verlust ist, da man nach kurzer Unterbrechung an einem meistens sehr naheliegenden Checkpoint respawnt. Es gibt also kein Mariotypisches-Lebenssystem.
Was ich auch hier betonen will, ist dass sich das Gameplay wieder sehr auf die Idee der Farben/der Bleiche beziehen, so verliert Koru, wenn er beinahe besiegt ist beispielsweise an Farbe oder Gegner f√ºllen sich mit Farbe, je frequentierter man sie schl√§gt.
Ich habe lediglich die empfohlene X-Box Controller Steuerung ausprobiert, die sich aber sehr intuitiv und angenehm "fl√ºssig" spielt. 


Die Grafik/Der Sound: 
1. Der Soundtrack ist meiner Meinung nach sehr gut gew√§hlt: passt; wird nicht langweilig und treibt an, w√§hrend sie aber auch entspannend wirkt und man sich irgendwie in dieser Welt "wohl f√ºhlt". Es gibt keine Sprachausgabe, lediglich Ger√§usche, die die Stimmung und den "Charakter" einer Person widerspiegeln.  
2. Die Grafik bzw. die gesamte Gestaltungsweise ist eine der gr√∂√üten St√§rken des Spiels und strotzt f√∂rmlich vor Ideenreichtum und wirkt immer sehr abgestimmt.
Das Charakterdesign ist wirklich, wirklich sch√∂n und dass die ganze Welt aus Pappe besteht ist einfach herausragend umgesetzt, da sich so ziemlich jede Textur und jeder Gegenstannd auf dieses Prinzip beruft. Es entsteht eine Homogene und trotzdem abwechselungsreiche Welt/Atmosph√§re, die ENDLICH mal nicht grau in grau in Matsch in grau ist! 
Bis jetzt, habe ich keine gr√∂√üeren Bildfehler oder matschige Texturen/Schatten o. √§. entdeckt. (Ich schlie√üe jedoch nicht aus, dass sie existieren.^^) 
Lediglich die Kameraf√ºhrung ist manchmal etwas chaotisch, besonders in den kurzen Phasen in denen man auf Seilen entlang rutscht.
Besonders hervorzuheben ist, dass das Spiel √ºber einen Farbenblinden-Modus verf√ºgt. 


Mein Fazit:
F√ºr mich funktioniert's! 
Es ist einfach alles in allem ein sehr rundes Paket und Grafik, Gameplay und Story gehen Hand in Hand um ihr Ziel zu erf√ºllen.

Ich pers√∂nlich f√ºhle mich wirklich ein wenig in die Jahre zur√ºckversetzt, als man sonntagmorgens den N64 rauskramte und sich mit seinen Br√ºdern um den Controller stritt. Ich kann mir vorstellen, dass dieses Spiel gerade bei Kindern sehr gut funktioniert und vor allem sehr gut zusammen mit kleineren Br√ºdern/Schwestern/oder Kindern spielbar ist.  
Dennoch schreit dir das Spiel nicht st√§ndig ins Gesicht: "Guck mal ich bin auch f√ºr Kinder geeignet."
(Koru hat beinahe Helden-Charakter und ich w√ºrde mich √ºber einen 2. Teil bzw. ein Spinn-Off oder irgendeine Fortsetzung sehr freuen. Mit anderen Worten: Eine Reihe, wie sie "The Legend of Zelda" fortf√ºhrt, die immer wieder eine neue Gameplay Idee in eine neue Welt packt. Und wer sagt denn, dass in Hyrule mehr Platz f√ºr ne Spielereihe ist, als in Tinkerworld)
 Ich h√§tte nicht wirklich erwartet, dass ein Entwickler-Studio, von dem man (bzw. Ich) bisher so wenig mitgekriegt hat, so ein Rundum-Paket abliefert, das sich was "traut" und die alte Schule auf so eine charmante, neue Weise aufleben l√§sst. Irgendwo ein Vorbild, f√ºr Triple-A-Studios.

Jedem, dem die Geschichte und die Welt bzw. die Aufmachung des Spiels zusagen, der sollte zuschlagen! 
(Allein schon, um zu beweisen, dass es eine Zielgruppe abseits von Nintendo gibt, die auf solche Spiele wartet!)
Falls einem allerdings der Stil des Spiels nicht gef√§llt, w√ºrde ich abraten.
Ich w√ºrde mich jedoch nicht von einer kindgerechten Verpackung abschrecken lassen! 

F√ºr mich schon jetzt ein Highlight 2014! Dringende Empfehlung f√ºr alle "90's Kids" und Nintendo-Konsolenkinder.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022750630', 'num_games_owned': 1623, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 550, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 550, 'last_played': 1402003060}
review:
The creators of The Last Tinker attempted to create a 3D-platformer like they were in the good old days about ten or fifteen years ago. The intentions are good, but unfortunately the creators must have thought the development of this genre during the last few years was a massive improvement. There certainly were improvements like ditching the classic live system or autosaving. But for me, on-rails-platforming is not an improvement.
On-rails-platforming means that the protagonist, Koru in the case of The Last Tinker, jumps automatically. You just walk around while holding a button and overcome the obstacles automatically. Some games like the AC series have an excuse for such a simplification: a lot of background stuff is going on which you have to keep track off, focussing on precise jumping all the time would be too hard. However, this excuse is not valid for The Last Tinker. 
Even though he refers to something slightly different, I would like to quote Ben Croshaw here: "[...] there's no challenge to this! This is not platforming, this is just walking down a very unusually-shaped corridor." [url=http://www.escapistmagazine.com/videos/view/zero-punctuation/2409-Enslaved-Odyssey-to-the-West?hq=1]Source (NSFW)[/url] 
Fortunately the developers of The Last Tinker made this observation as well and included timing sections to add 
some challenge to the platforming. (For the record, the same holds for the developers of Enslaved.) 

Enough about the "platforming", let us look at other aspects of the game. It is rich in variety after all.  There is some combat, of course, the common button-smashing combo-based combat. There are some railsliding sections, where you have to continuously switch between rails to not smash into obstacles. And there are many puzzles of various types which are usually nice, but not diffifcult. 

What I really like about The Last Tinker is that it tells its story not exclusively by the means of cutscenes and dialogues, but also by the environment itself. You can literally see how the city is estranged and united again.

Conclusion: The Last Tinker has its weaknesses, but it shines in other aspects. It is not challenging, but also doesn't get boring easily. Overall The Last Tinker offers a very nice experience.

review: This game is seriously charming. I've missed these 3d puzzle platformers, and while it isn't as lengthy or witty as Banjo Kazooie, The Last Tinker has definitely felt fun and familiar. The colours are gorgeous and the story is really quite sweet! Exploring the dichotomies of strength/anger, curiosity/fear through these little spirit elemental guys as you adventure through Colortown was super enjoyable, and I'd totally recommend it if you're after something fun and easy to play through.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057960337', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 545, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 545, 'last_played': 1403969654}
review:
Auf den ersten Blick mag "The Last Tinker: City of Colors" wie ein Kinderspiel wirken, macht aber auch Erwachsenen Spa√ü. Behaupte ich jetzt einfach mal, schlie√ülich bin ich ja schon l√§nger erwachsen. Und vorab, weil sich das nicht richtig in Pro und Kontra einsortieren l√§sst - die Story ist f√ºr Kinder sicher toll, ansonsten jedoch auch ohne gro√üe √úberraschungen.

Pro:
- s√º√üer, stimmiger Grafikstil 
- viele liebevolle Details, Animationen und Emotionen
- situationsbezogener toller Soundtrack
- immer wieder neue Herausforderungen & R√§tsel
- Tap als Hilfe, wenn man mal nicht wusste, wo's weiter ging
- mehrere Schwierigkeitsgrade von "kinderleicht" bis "soforttot"
- freischaltbare Artworks durch Schwebepinsel

Kontra:
- zu wenig und zu weit entfernte Speicherpunkte (Speicherpunkte wenigstens nach Boss K√§mpfen w√§ren schon durchaus praktisch gewesen)
- automatisches Springen funktionierte nicht immer hundertprotzentig
- Protagonist selbst gefiel mir von allen Charakteren am wenigsten - sah halt schon sehr nach einem Affen aus, aber dadurch lie√ü er sich ja wunderbar von anderen NPCs immer als Affengesicht beschimpfen. Muss also Absicht gewesen sein.

Und mehr negatives will mir gerade einfach nicht einfallen. Glaube, das ist also nicht so wirklich ein negativer Punkt f√ºr das Spiel ;). Mir hat es also Spa√ü gemacht, ich war von kleinen Details fasziniert und blieb √∂fter mal stehen, damit ich mir das alles genauer anschauen kann. Besonders gefielen mir auch Biggs & Bomber, die auf die unterschiedlichen Farben nicht nur mit unterschiedlichen Auswirkungen, sondern auch Stimmungen reagiert haben, die grafisch aber auch soundtechnisch gut r√ºberkamen.

Wenn das jetzt f√ºr jemanden alles interessant klingt, dann - nur zu, es lohnt sich! :)

Questi i primi aggettivi che ci vengono in mente per descrivere The Last Tinker: City of Colors, action-platform (con qualche inflessione puzzle) di Mimimi Productions ed Unity Games uscito pochi giorni fa su Steam per Pc Windows, Mac e Linux.

Un titolo indie dall‚Äôanimo semplice che strizza l‚Äôocchio al passato offrendo un gameplay intuitivo e senza troppi fronzoli che lascia spazio all‚Äôazione pi√π pura alternandola ad alcuni spunti di riflessione per spezzare il ritmo concedendo attimi ragionati per risolvere i puzzle che il gioco presenta.

review: This was fun. It wasn't quite what I was expecting when I heard it was inspired by Jak and Daxter, but despite a boring beginning I ended up enjoying it. I would have preferred a full 3D platformer instead of the free running, and more open exploration instead of the linear structure, but the puzzles and combat ended up being interesting. The developers created a very nice world to spend some time in.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985215786', 'num_games_owned': 2073, 'num_reviews': 199, 'playtime_forever': 365, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1486422436}
review:
Dei colori sgargianti e dell‚Äôambientazione favolesca di The Last Tinker: City Of Colors ve ne avevamo gi√† anticipato poco pi√π di un mesetto fa. La prova aveva convinto facilmente, anche per via di alcuni accorgimenti che strizzavano l‚Äôocchio a grandi classici del genere, pur non ricordandone alcuno in particolare. Finalmente, per√≤, il gioco di Mimimi Productions √® uscito e posso affermare con gioia che √® stato un vero piacere giocarlo.

Per i pi√π pigri, sappiate che parliamo di un gioco d‚Äôavventura dalle componenti platform e puzzle che, mescolate con i tanti colori presenti dell‚Äôambientazione, mirano a offrire un miscuglio di gameplay dall‚Äôapproccio fortemente intuitivo. In effetti, a essere onesti, The Last Tinker: City Of Colors non √® proprio un gioco dal target adulto: l‚Äôintera vicenda, i modi in cui √® trattata e i personaggi stessi rivelano immediatamente l‚Äôintento pedagogico ed educativo del titolo. Questo, per√≤, non deve essere assolutamente preso come un elemento negativo, anzi! Visti i temi trattati, quali razzismo e bullismo, il gioco dei ragazzi tedeschi non farebbe di certo male a tutte le belle teste maggiorenni e simpatiche che stanno facendo notizia negli ultimi tempi. Ad ogni modo, seguiremo le vicende della scimmietta Koru e del suo compare Tap (un maialino che potremo evocare per ritrovare l‚Äôeventuale strada smarrita) i quali saranno alle prese con una colorata crisi distruttiva. Pur non avendo chiss√† che profondit√†, preferisco non anticipare nulla sulla trama che, in piccolissime dosi, cercher√† di intrattenere e affascinare anche il giocatore pi√π esperto.

Il vero fulcro di The Last Tinker, per√≤, √® decisamente il sistema di gioco. Valutarlo come un mero gioco per bambini sarebbe tanto ridicolo quanto ingiusto. Prima di tutto, nonostante i toni fanciulleschi, The Last Tinker non perder√† modo per impegnare il giocatore nel cercare soluzioni a enigmi pi√π o meno complessi, attraverso elementi ambientali, abilit√† uniche dei personaggi e lo studio stesso dei comportamenti dei nemici in caso di trappole ad area. In pi√π, il livello di variet√† delle situazioni proposte rende il gioco di Mimimi Productions qualcosa di costantemente in evoluzione, eliminando del tutto quelle formule di gioco (presenti in prodotti ben pi√π ‚Äúmaturi‚Äù e complessi) in cui si alternano nettamente momenti da materia grigia ad altri di button mashing selvaggio in zone chiuse. Bench√© il gioco sia diviso in aree ben delineate, questa separazione rimarr√† sempre molto latente, sia per via dei caricamenti molto rapidi, sia per una struttura dei livelli che tutto far√† tranne che farvi sentire persi.

Tra inseguimenti scapicollanti, esplorazioni in cerca di pennelli nascosti e scontri con nemici di vario tipo, troveremo pane per i nostri denti sotto ogni aspetto. In particolare, una volta raggiunto il fulcro di Colortown, potremo approfondire quegli aspetti che saranno via via presentati al giocatore, uno fra tutti il sistema di combattimento ‚Äî che ricorda tantissimo quello di Rocksteady e dei recenti Batman. Gli scontri non sono tanti, n√© troppo complessi (a riguardo, consiglio di giocare almeno al livello Difficile, se non a morte istantanea), ma la nostra libert√† di approccio si andr√† sempre rimpinzando di abilit√† e colpi particolari che rendono gli scontri ancora pi√π divertenti. Il tutto gira sempre attorno ai colori di Tinkerworld e ai loro poteri; per esempio, con i colpi rossi faremo dei danni, con quelli verdi faremo scappare i nemici toccati. Questa incredibile cura dei dettagli, sia a livello di meccaniche, che a livello di background, rende The Last Tinker: City Of Colors una di quelle favole che anche da adulti non dispiace affatto seguire. Il lavoro che √® stato effettuato per dare credibilit√† (per un bambino, cos√¨ per un giocatore cresciuto) all‚Äôintero contesto di gioco √® superlativo, cos√¨ come √® ottima la caratterizzazione dei personaggi, per quanto sempliciotta, e la diversit√† dei nemici offerti che vi spingeranno a sperimentare le combinazioni degli attacchi.

Pi√π che cercare i possibili difetti di The Last Tinker: City Of Colors (forse un sistema di controllo raramente poco preciso), quello che mi interessa √® ribadire ancora una volta come l‚Äôiniziale aspetto infantile del titolo non debba affatto trarre in inganno. Forse √® proprio questa la croce e delizia del gioco di Mimimi Productions: avere un potenziale enorme, un gameplay studiato e realizzato a pennello, ma dover necessariamente rischiare di essere ignorato per via di un approccio pi√π semplice alla struttura ludica. Ripeto: non si tratta affatto di un difetto, il gioco riesce perfettamente a rapire giovani e ‚Äúanziani‚Äù, ma √® indubbio come qualcuno storcer√† il naso perch√© mancano elementi random tra sangue, poppe, cicatrici sul volto, capelli da Super Saiyan, sesso o amenit√† che laggente √® solita definire come ‚Äúmature‚Äù. Fidatevi del buon Kelvo e date ascolto al bimbo che c‚Äô√® in voi: The Last Tinker: City Of Colors √® un gioco che vi rapir√† dal primo momento con la sua semplicit√†. Tutto a un tratto vi ritroverete a voler andare avanti per sapere come finisce la storia e allora s√¨ che vi riguarderete indietro e noterete che avete passato un intero pomeriggio nei panni di una scimmietta colorata con berretto e sciarpa. Il prezzo di 20 euro √® pi√π he giustificato per l‚Äôalta qualit√† dei contenuti, della grafica (mossa con il motore Unity) e del comparto sonoro presente che allieter√† con brani allegri e spensierati.

8

Consigliato a: chiunque, parliamo di un gioco d‚Äôavventura con enigmi che ricalca i grandi classici come Spyro, Pandemonium e Crash Bandicoot, chi cerca un gioco piattaforma sopraffino, chi vuole un titolo poco impegnativo ma divertente, chi cerca un passatempo per i propri figli senza dover rinunciare al proprio divertimento.

Sconsigliato a: chi non √® pi√π in grado di ridere, chi ha dimenticato cosa significa essere bambini e chi non lo √® mai stato. Sfigati.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004633274', 'num_games_owned': 1916, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 914, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1408679646}
review: The Last Tinker is a gorgeous, harmless romp of a game with lots of charm, but this may be a game best suited for children old enough not to re-enact Koru‚Äôs fighting moves on their siblings. I found the game very easy (except for the rail segments) and between the lack of a challenge or a gripping storyline, I had difficulty staying engaged to the end. However, this would likely be a fantastic game for parents to play with their children, and as such, it gets a solid recommendation from me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967608993', 'num_games_owned': 2393, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 561, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 561, 'last_played': 1400952518}
review:
The Last Tinker‚Ñ¢: City of Colors ist mit seinem Bastellook nicht nur eine Augenweide, sondern setzt sich dadurch auch von den eher d√ºsteren Umgebungen in der Computerspielbranche ab. Spielerisch ist es als Actionadventure anzusehen. Die Sprungeinlagen, welche in der Assassins Creed √ºblichen schau wohin du willst und dr√ºck den Knopf ablaufen wirken am Anfang noch leicht, werden aber im verlauf des Spieles zunehmender vom Timing abh√§ngig.

Die Steuerung ist, obwohl es sich um eine PC Version handelt auf ein Gamepad ausgelegt und mit diesem am besten zu steuern. Da die Farben der Tasten 1:1 den Farben im Spiel gleichen.

Zum Spielgeschehen sollte noch gesagt werden, dass es nicht wie andere Spiele schnell zu Sache kommt, sondern sich von Anfang bis Ende viel Zeit l√§sst. Manchmal zu viel Zeit.

Zum negativen am ganzen Spiel geh√∂rt leider das Kampfsystem, da es in diesem schnell zu einer Verkettung von Schadensarten (Gegner trifft einen und schubst einen in Stacheln) kommt und mal schnell seine ganze Energie verliert. Vor allem beim Endboss kann es vorkommen, dass er den Spieler √ºber die ganze Arena Schubst und bei jeder Ber√ºhrung Schaden verursacht.

Ich pers√∂nlich kann dieses Spiel aber dennoch jedem Empfehlen und rate hiermit auch gleich zu der Version mit Soundtrack, da dieser doch zu einen der besseren der Branche geh√∂rt.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008561308', 'num_games_owned': 416, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 476, 'last_played': 1400457114}
review:
What is there to say about a game like this. One that apes nostalgia so much and one that really does bring back that feeling of classic PSX/N64 platforming? Anyone that knows me, knows that some of my favorite games growing up were Spyro, Gex, Sly Cooper, and Banjo Kazooie just to name a few. I absolutely adored 3D platformers when I was a kid. Seeing something like this pop up on steam out of the blue was a very real, very welcome surprise. 

In a world of countless dark, edgy brown and grey, dirty games, Mimimi Productions picked the perfect time to put this game out there. It's strikingly bold color pallette was enough to catch my eye, and after not only watching the start of a live stream with the dev, but speaking to one of the devs herself/himself who was nice enough to answer my many questions on the game, I knew this was a company that deserved every penny. 

Let's be extremely clear on this: This is a kid's game. There is no deep rooted meaning and the colorism "Seperating of colors being bad" undertone is about as subtle as a brick through a plate glass window. On the upside, it's not so overbearing that a young child could easily grasp it at first. There are plenty of references for long time gamers and a lot of enjoyment to be had with this title with little ones if for no other reason than it being a colorful distraction for a few hours.

THIS PART CONTAINS A SPOILER...
Now onto the one gripe that struck me right at the very end. Once you reach the end of the game, there's no going back to a fully united colortown to complete side objectives and such. To pick up all the brushes and "complete" the game. This is a pretty big gripe unfortunately because it kind of undermines all that you went through to get the town united. Not being able to see the fully realized colortown with all the districts means you don't really feel fulfillef at the very end. Sure you CAN go back to previous chapters and collect the brushes, but you'll be replaying the game essentially with the bleakness still around, again, undermining all the work you put in and the adventure you just went on. I don't know if this was a conscious decision or if it was a limitation, but it's the one gripe that I had to really dig down to see if it was worth mentioning, and I feel it is.

NO MORE SPOILERS...
So what are my final thoughts on the game? For the demographic it was made for, and for long time fans of classic 3D platformers I highly suggest picking it up if for no other reason than nostalgia. Unique character designs, bright and colorful color pallette, overall upbeat game with an interesting twist about halfway in. It's a really good game, and to hear that it's not only from an indie dev, but this being their FIRST indie game released? I fully support this group going forward and I can't wait to see what they make in the future!

author: {'steamid': '76561198001537918', 'num_games_owned': 362, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 781, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 781, 'last_played': 1401236913}
review:
Wer alte Adventure Spiele wie Croc, Spyro oder Banjo Kazooi gespielt und geliebt hat, wird seinen Spa√ü mit The Last Tinker: City of Colors haben. Es ist ein Adventure Spiel der alten Schule, die in dieser Form heutzutage (warum auch immer) kaum noch entwickelt werden. Doch endlich k√∂nnen Fans dieses Genre sich in ein neues Abenteuer st√ºrzen.

Die Spielwelt ist so Bunt, wie sie nur sein kann und strotzt geradezu mit lauter kleinen niedlichen Details. Der Protagonist hei√üt Koru und ist wie der Titel des Spiels schon erahnen l√§sst, der letzte Tinker. Das Spiel ist sehr abwechslungsreich, so gibt es z.B Level, die aus altbekannten Jump 'n' Run Passagen bestehen, aber auch Level wo man z.B einen Kriminalfall l√∂sen muss (Der √ºbrigens extrem gut inszeniert ist und viel Spa√ü macht). Im Laufe des Spiels bekommt man auch immer wieder neue F√§higkeiten, die das Spiel nochmal abwechslungsreicher machen.

Die Durchschnittliche Spielzeit betr√§gt 8 Stunden. In den meisten Leveln sind Pinsel versteckt die man sammeln kann und mit denen man spezielle Gimmicks wie z.B einen "Gro√üe K√∂pfe"-Modus freischalten kann. Aus diesem Grund lohnt es sich, nach dem ersten Durchlauf nochmal in den Leveln vorbeizuschauen, um die restlichen Pinsel zu finden, die man vorher √ºbersehen hat.

Eine klare Kaufempfehlung von mir.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995878602', 'num_games_owned': 448, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 338, 'last_played': 1400685960}

author: {'steamid': '76561197979084213', 'num_games_owned': 4499, 'num_reviews': 1010, 'playtime_forever': 630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 571, 'last_played': 1400354493}
review:
The Last Tinker is a colorful 3D platformer that succeeds on many levels, but, as always, there's definitely room for improvement:

+ Parkour running feels and works great
+ Just long enough (7-9 hours) before it becomes (too) boring
+ Has a bit more variety in its objectives/Tries to mix things up 3/4 into the game

+/- Combat tries to mimic the combat from the Batman games but partially fails because it doesn't work as fluently
+/- Graphics are colorful and abstract, but there's too little variety in the environments, except for certain colors
+/- The puzzles are casual and therefore on the easy side, but still fun to solve

- The parts that are on-rails are sometimes awkward to control and you sometimes can't see too far ahead which results in the character getting hit or even dying
- Story and characters are a bit childish sometimes

[Rating: 74/100]

author: {'steamid': '76561198014624970', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 511, 'last_played': 1399583852}
review: Pari largement r√©ussi pour Mimimi Productions ! Avec The Last Tinker : City of Colors, les Allemands livrent un jeu d'excellente facture, √† la r√©alisation irr√©prochable. L'ambition des d√©veloppeurs, caract√©ris√©e par un renouvellement constant du gameplay, et l'utilisation du moteur graphique Unity permettent au titre de jouer dans la cour des grands. Les huit heures n√©cessaires pour terminer l'aventure offrent suffisamment de vari√©t√© pour ne pas s'ennuyer une seconde, et le message, d'un optimisme na√Øf touchant sans jamais √™tre b√™tifiant ou r√©ducteur, plaira √† un public plus large que la simple cible enfantine. The Last Tinker d√©montre fi√®rement que la fronti√®re entre petites productions et mastodontes de l'industrie se fait de plus en plus poreuse.

"The Last Tinker: City of Colors est un jeu de plateforme avec une direction artistique superbe √† tous les niveaux (musical, visuel et sc√©naristique) ainsi qu‚Äôun gameplay minutieusement travaill√©, vari√©, √©volutif et techniquement au top alors qu'il aurait √©t√© facile de se reposer sur ses lauriers et de b√¢cler ce genre de jeu, sous pr√©texte qu'il s'agirait d'un jeu pour enfants.

Du coup, on nous propose un soft certes assez facile, mais avec un charme ind√©niable qui va pouvoir plaire √† tous les types de joueurs, et qui n‚Äôa surtout rien √† envier √† ses mod√®les Banjo-Kazooie, Jak et Daxter et certainement Rayman 2. The Last Tinker est donc un excellent jeu d‚Äôaventure-plateforme en 3D, comme l'on n'en fait plus, et qui rend hommage aux l√©gendes du genre parfois m√™me en les surpassant en termes qualit√©. Une excellente surprise √† n‚Äôen pas douter, et, malgr√© un d√©but de jeu un tout petit peu lent et quelques petits probl√®mes tr√®s mineurs, un bon gros coup de c≈ìur pour sa qualit√© g√©n√©rale, sa beaut√© et son originalit√©."

author: {'steamid': '76561197996501124', 'num_games_owned': 7813, 'num_reviews': 182, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1407018453}
review: One of the promises of the next generation of video games has been a departure from the grimdark gray color scheme that has seemed to permeate a good majority of the industry since Gears of War premiered way back in 2006. Titles like Sunset Overdrive and Titanfall have reminded gamers that there is a gloriously varied color palette out there. The story told in The Last Tinker: City of Colors seems to coincidentally mirror this emerging trend. The Last Tinker is a fully featured platformer set in a beautiful fantasy world with stunning graphics and CG characters that could easily be on Nickelodeon instead of fully controllable with a gamepad. It seems to be geared for kids, but N64 era fans of all ages will find something to like the world of Colortown.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995205831', 'num_games_owned': 534, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1007, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1007, 'last_played': 1399692820}
review:
Today, I‚Äôll be talking about The Last Tinker: City of Colors. The Last Tinker is a puzzle/platformer for the PC from developer Mimimi Productions, which up until now has only developed mobile games. It‚Äôs the first game of it‚Äôs kind that I‚Äôve played since my childhood with Spyro on the PS1. It‚Äôs completely different from the FPS games I play today. It was delightfully entertaining and easy to enjoy. The gameplay harkened back to the days of Ratchet & Clank or Banjo-Kazooie. The childlike art style was colorful and calming, as was the music. You are Koru, the ape-like protaganist.

Read the full review here: http://www.crypticgames.com/reviews/2014/05/the-last-tinker-city-of-colors-review/

author: {'steamid': '76561198022997080', 'num_games_owned': 2142, 'num_reviews': 388, 'playtime_forever': 548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 548, 'last_played': 1400449496}
review:
The Last Tinker: City of Color might as well be a response to my silent yearnings for a generation of games that have all but died off. A vibrant 3D platformer, it aligns with both my love of games such as Super Mario 64 and Sly Cooper, as well as my disappointment with so many modern games‚Äô dull pallets. But although outwardly it appears to have every element needed to position itself as a modern classic in a dying genre, when broken down it would be hard to mistake it for more than a facade; a game that at times looks and feels like those it tries so hard to emulate, but will never stand among them.

Colortown is, as the name suggests, a world full of and built on color. Everything is crafted from paper, glue, and the creator‚Äôs imagination, creating a wonderfully bright and lively place to inhabit. But the citizens of Colortown don‚Äôt see it quite the same, having become disquieted with those who do not share their same color and splitting off into rival clans. The last bastion of unity resides in a slum of sorts, where we find Koru, the last of a race known as the Tinkers and the only one who may be able to bring Colortown back together after he unknowingly calls forth a bleakness that threatens to rid the world of all color permanently.

The Last Tinker doesn‚Äôt attempt a very ambitious plot, and its racial undertones and messages against othering are about as subtle as a brick careening through your window. It‚Äôs a simple narrative that nonetheless proves unexpectedly entertaining for reasons I can‚Äôt quite describe. Characters are flat yet quirky enough that I didn‚Äôt dislike talking to them, and the dialog while basic is didn‚Äôt annoy me the way so many kids games tend to. The end segments unfortunately descend into a thick coat of heavy handed racism and the power of friendship with about as much grace as you would expect from this sort of game, but I was still surprised by how much I enjoyed the story despite it having every reason to fall on its face.

While I call it a platformer, the actual platforming isn‚Äôt quite what you might expect. Utilizing an auto running/jumping mechanic similar to the Assassin‚Äôs Creed series, you aren‚Äôt required so much to jump from platform to platform as you are to hold down a button and direct your character which way to go. It‚Äôs extremely simplistic in nature, but to my surprise actually works well for the game more often than not. It‚Äôs fluid and very forgiving, which for a game presumably aimed at kids works well and makes it even more accessible than most of the genre. The levels you run through however are far less satisfying, rarely putting the excellently designed mechanic to anything more advanced than you‚Äôll see within the first few minutes of the game, often relying on long tedious segments of empty terrain occasionally broken up by an impromptu enemy encounter (from which spawn further problems).

If the platforming is an example of how to make uncomplicated mechanics interesting, the combat system is the exact opposite; a dreadfully monotonous lesson in repetition and over simplification, that although never difficult proved frustrating merely because of how often it intruded on the other elements of the game. It easily ranks among the dullest button mashers I‚Äôve encountered, and the input lag took a considerable amount of time to adjust to (by which I mean to say I got used to it, not that it ever became enjoyable). You gain a handful of powers through the course of the game, but these rarely amount to more than a novelty (a power to make enemies run away, become frozen from sadness, etc) that rarely work when executed outside of areas purposely designed to show you how they function.

Platforming and combat are easily the most prominent components to the game, but they aren‚Äôt what you will be doing most of the time. Instead of running through obstacle courses or beating up baddies, you‚Äôll spend a majority of the 5-6 hour experience running from one place to the next, only to find when you get there that you need to continue running to an entirely new area. This is my biggest gripe with The Last Tinker; it builds up an amazing world and sends you running through it as if its building to a point where you‚Äôll finally see the mechanics expanded upon (or at least put to greater use), only to have it end and leave you realizing how little time was actually spent doing anything of interest. It‚Äôs tedious and almost feels dishonest, but most of all it‚Äôs just a shame that so much time was put into crafting the outstanding presentation for the gameplay to not get anywhere near the same sort of attention, which ultimately makes the former rather superfluous.

Be that as it may, I couldn‚Äôt end this without mentioning the truly fantastic art design and soundtrack Mimimi Productions has created. Color bursts out of every inch of the world, spilling over the Dr Seuss like landscapes and twisting architecture, filled with bizarrely cute characters that each feel distinct for the region they inhabit. It‚Äôs like someone went absolutely crazy during arts and crafts, and built an entire city out of clay and cardboard, which would actually be rather fitting given that‚Äôs essentially what the lore tells you happened. The soundtrack was the surprise highlight though, with an eclectic collection of styles ranging from soothing accordion pieces to catchy guitar riffs and sweeping orchestral tracks. It ranges a huge spectrum of sounds and surprisingly nails each one with more finesse than most games manage with a single style, and somehow makes them all sit naturally next to one another.

The Last Tinker isn‚Äôt a hopeless mess by any means, but I was left disappointed by what could have potentially been so much more. I appreciate the developers making it accessible to kids, but doing so in such a way as to make it actively dull for those out of that stage of development makes it a hard game to recommend to anyone over the age of ten. Even putting the mechanical shortcomings aside, the unengaging and empty level designs make it a game that feels hollow; clearly missing something even when you can‚Äôt quite figure out what it is. It‚Äôs a lovely game to look at and features an excellent audio accompaniment, but it amounts to little more than smoke and mirrors once you realize how much was sacrificed in other areas of the game to make it possible.

[b]Full disclosure: this game was reviewed using a copy provided by the developer[/b]
